abstract: Mr. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, said the trade-off to his own privacy was worthwhile, if the disclosure that he is gay could help others.
snippet: Mr. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, said the trade-off to his own privacy was worthwhile, if the disclosure that he is gay could help others.
lead_paragraph: Tim Cook’s declaration on Thursday that “I’m proud to be gay” made him the first publicly gay chief executive of a Fortune 500 company. But Mr. Cook isn’t just any chief executive. And Apple isn’t any company. It’s one of the most profitable companies in the Fortune 500 and ranks No. 1 on the magazine’s annual ranking of the most admired companies.

headline.main: The Coming Out of Apple’s Tim Cook: ‘This Will Resonate’
headline.print_headline: Apple Chief’s Coming Out: ‘This Will Resonate’

abstract: Mr. Cook said coming out publicly was worth it “if hearing that the C.E.O. of Apple is gay can help someone struggling to come to terms with who he or she is.”
snippet: Mr. Cook said coming out publicly was worth it “if hearing that the C.E.O. of Apple is gay can help someone struggling to come to terms with who he or she is.”
lead_paragraph: Timothy D. Cook’s declaration on Thursday that “I’m proud to be gay” made him the first publicly gay chief executive of a Fortune 500 company. But Mr. Cook isn’t just any chief executive, James B. Stewart writes in his Common Sense column. And Apple isn’t any company. It’s one of the most profitable companies in the Fortune 500 and ranks No. 1 on the magazine’s annual ranking of the most admired companies.

headline.main: Daily Report: The Power of Tim Cook’s Declaration

abstract: So far, a payment-processing executive said, businesses fall into one of three buckets: “those who actively want to use it, those who are exploring it and those that want to wait and see.”
snippet: So far, a payment-processing executive said, businesses fall into one of three buckets: “those who actively want to use it, those who are exploring it and those that want to wait and see.”
lead_paragraph: With the introduction of Apple Pay, many small-business owners are weighing whether they should take the necessary steps to accept the new form of payment.

headline.main: Small Businesses Assess Their Apple Pay Options

abstract: Citigroup says it has to cut its third-quarter profit by $600 million because of legal expenses. | Apple chief’s coming out. | Judge approves bankruptcy plan for Stockton, Calif.
snippet: Citigroup says it has to cut its third-quarter profit by $600 million because of legal expenses. | Apple chief’s coming out. | Judge approves bankruptcy plan for Stockton, Calif.
lead_paragraph: CITIGROUP CUTS THIRD-QUARTER PROFIT | Citigroup can’t seem to catch a break. On Thursday, the bank startled investors with an announcement that it had to lower its third-quarter profit by $600 million because of “rapidly evolving regulatory inquiries and investigations,” DealBook’s Michael Corkery, Peter Eavis and Ben Protess write. Citigroup reported its results for the quarter two weeks ago, just before the legal development arose. Although the bank did not specify the development, people briefed on the matter attributed the nearly 18 percent drop in earnings to an investigation into whether Citigroup manipulated the price of foreign currencies. Since reporting its third-quarter results, the bank has edged nearer a settlement with at least one regulator in the case, the people said.
